conversations.content: You're lost in thought, Chelle. This frightens me.
I don't think a little reminiscing goes amiss when we are going to be away from Chanzelia for some time, no?
That's rather maudlin and unlike mew.
Rude. Even one such as I can be given to such flights now and again, particularly when it comes to the Radiant City.
...Mmm, it was quite the tumultuous experience when we first arrived.
Indeed. How many years has it been now?
Several years prior...
Well, we're here in Raywall at last.
These northern reaches are so very far from the capital—how purr-sitively unfair of King Aurelius to toss a princess into a tepid backwater such as this!
Raywall is a key strategic position that overlooks the northern border; it is vital that the royal family strengthen our relations with this place.
I suspect my dear father left it to me because it is a role none but I can perform.
I suppose...
Is there something you wish to share?
Not a single thing.
Mmm, I see. Shall we be going, then?
I am pleased to meet you, Your Highness. It is the honor of a lifetime to welcome you to our fair city.
The Marquis of Raywall has bade me permit you to make full and free use of this mansion for your purposes.
Should you require anything else at all, you have but to let me know.
My deepest thanks—however, I would prefer to greet the marquis in person. Where might he be?
That will not be necessary, Your Highness. For today, it is his wish that you rest and recover from the rigors of your journey.
The marquis himself will call on you in some days' time for a proper meeting.
Please inform me if you have any concerns, Your Highness. Until then.
In other words, he wants us to stay put and mind our meow-ners.
It's quite the chilly reception, isn't it? Whatever did you do to them?
I assure you, I have done nothing. My grandfather, on the other hand...
You mean the purr-evious king of Alberia?
The very same. You see, Raywall is not only a strategic point with respect to the border, but a prosperous city thanks to its trade routes with other lands.
However, Grandfather—that is, the former Alberian king—launched an invasion of the Holy City of Grams across the border.
This had the effect of harming foreign sentiment towards us. Trade collapsed, and Raywall's entire economy sustained a near-lethal blow.
As soon as my father took the throne, he agreed to an armistice—but that did not mean things could simply go back to how they once had been.
Mrawr hawr hawr! I suppose they're right to be upset, seeing as how your family went out and started the war.
Things may have yet worked out had that been the whole of it, but alas...
Mrowr?
My grandfather's war lacked a just cause, which is why Father was ready to end it.
And yet, human emotions are an infinitely complex thing.
You meown to say that there were some in Raywall who opposed the ceasefire? Whyever for?
Raywall bore the brunt of its war, and I am given to understand that many lost parents and siblings during the conflict.
Just because the war had ended did not mean that animosity for the enemy disappeared along with it.
Ah, NOW I see! So there are some in this city who wish to go to war with Grams once more, even without just cause.
Thus, mew have been sent to keep such rash minds in check.
As ever, you demonstrate the keen insight of the pactwyrm in whom I place my trust.
My duty is to find the half-wits trying to start a war and make them fall in line.
Now it makes sense—I knew you never would have gone along with the plan without some secondary reason.
Actually, that plan is, in fact, my true objective.
Mrowl?! Then you are truly going to...?
I am indeed, my dear Cat Sìth.
I have come to this city to be married, and I intend to see it done.
Is that the third scion of Alberia?! Princess Chelle?!
A member of the royal family's got some nerve showing their face here in Raywall.
I'm of the understanding she is to be wed to the marquis.
Sending his daughter to curry favor, eh? It's plain as day what the king's thinking!
They certainly don't hold back in this town. And here I was under the impression this was supposed to be your welcoming party.
Actually, I find it almost refreshing how they wear their true preferences right on their gilded sleeves.
Still, I suppose it best to educate those who are so woefully unaware of proper decorum during social interaction.
Mrow?!
I am so very pleased to make your acquaintance, honored guests! I am the third scion of Alberia, Princess Chelle.
What nerve to come over here! You're either fearless or brainless— I don't know which.
I simply understand the norms of proper etiquette, General Bertrand.
You know of me, then?
I would not dare come to Raywall without knowledge of the storied general who single-handedly leads its military.
May I presume the esteemed personages behind you are Secretary Constantin and the Lady Doriane, Baroness of Bonnard?
Your providence does you credit indeed, that you would study so diligently in effort to secure a place in our good graces.
Oh, I've studied other things as well— including the young artist called Vincent.
Ah! Er...I'm afraid I don't know what you are talking about.
He is said to be a young and nameless painter, though of late I hear he built an atelier most grand. You are unfamiliar?
M-most unfamiliar!
Goodness, is that so? It was my understanding that you frequented the young man's workshop, Baroness.
...As recently as last afternoon, even.
How could you know that?!
Eee hee hee! Perhaps it would do simply to say that a curious little kitten whispered it to me in passing.
Intimidation through blackmail hardly befits one of your standing, Princess.
And such words hardly befit a general. Or perhaps you are the sort who charges into battles without strategy or plan?
If you are one to lead such an army, I would be better served to take the tales of Raywall's great military with a  grain of salt—or even the entire shaker.
I say! Princess or no, I will not tolerate such contempt for Raywall!
I am showing no contempt whatsoever! Merely discussing a hypothetical.
If the army is NOT, in fact, a band of feckless warriors, then I am certain its general would understand the way in which I choose to do battle.
Nnngh...
I think that's quite enough ＂enthusiasm,＂ for one day, everyone.
Marquis.
A pleasure to meet you, Princess Chelle. I am the Marquis of Raywall, but I pray you do me the honor of calling me Elua.
Though I suspect you already know of me.
Most certainly—though it casts a decidedly different shade in the memory having been greeted in person versus having not.
For example, one might modify appropriately their petting of a kitten if it were baring its fangs, no?
Gracious me, it seems as though the others here may have carelessly stepped upon a dragon's tail.
It would seem so. I apologize for my impropriety, Highness.
Not at all, General. I myself have on occasion been known to take things rather too far—let us simply say that there has been impropriety on both our behalves.
However, I would have you bear in mind that our feelings towards the royal family are...complicated. Now then, if you will please excuse me?
Permit me to greet you once more, Your Highness—or perhaps I ought to simply call you my betrothed?
The honor is mine, dear fiancé. Ah, but my heart has been aflutter, wondering what sort of man my husband-in-waiting might turn out to be.
And what are your impressions now that you have beheld the man in person?
They are positive indeed. Beyond that... Well, we shall simply have to see how things develop in the days to come.
A most frightening thought; I shall endeavor not to disappoint.
And what are your impressions of me?
I am intrigued. If you will forgive me a bit of bluntness, I had heard you were a rather self-absorbed princess, and was surprised this union was allowed to proceed.
You suspected I would never have acceded to a political marriage?
I did. However, as it was decided upon with a surprising degree of readiness, I felt you were also the type who set aside her own happiness for that of her house.
Though I might be royalty, in the end I am little more than a bird in a gilded cage.
So I thought—but your recent exchange has made me reconsider that assumption.
It made me feel as though you are indeed a woman who knows the meaning of nobility—and of being waited upon.
Whatever do you mean, sir?
This is but a theory of mine, but I see nobility as something not decided by those above, but by those below.
It is only because our vassals and people acknowledge us as noble that we aristocrats can BE noble.
To perpetuate that, we must protect our vassals and people while maintaining an environment in which they can quite readily recognize our nobility.
One such method is a political marriage, and I imagine your understanding of this fact lead you to acquiesce to our union.
...Well? How did I do?
All this time, Lord Elua, I have had a thought:
What an efficient thing, political marriage!
So efficient, I think, that there is no better method for manipulating both popular and political sentiment.
Yet even in high society, there are many who avoid such unions, which is foolishness to the extreme.
Such people know nothing and less about what nobility actually is.
Nobility is, by nature, a meaningless thing. People do not inherently have degrees of value, yet we impose rank upon them, and so nobility is born.
Just so. And to ascribe value to such an empty thing, we've no avenue other than to humor, soothe, and distract.
Indeed, those of noble rank must soothe the people so they might welcome such palliatives with gladness in their hearts.
Avoiding what is necessary to accomplish that puts one worlds apart from the notion of nobility.
Heh... Eee hee hee!
Princess Chelle?
I confess, despite my interest in the Marquis of Raywall, I have had little interest in YOU, Lord Elua.
Yet this conversation has set my opinion in quite the opposite direction.
I trust I may take that as praise?
You may. Ah, it seems as though I will like this city far more than I anticipated.
...And you as well, Lord Elua.
Lord Caspar? Priestess Aurelia? Might I introduce to you my fiancée?
I am Princess Chelle, and I am most pleased to make your acquaintances.
I have heard much about you, Princess— and I see the tales of your great beauty have not been exaggerated.
You are far too kind.
Wedding a princess of the royal family will surely help Raywall's prosperity grow more and more, Lord Elua.
My thanks, Lord Caspar, though such prosperity is thanks in no small part to those from the Holy City of Grams— yourself included.
I hope we might continue to enjoy a prosperous exchange in the years to come.
Let us permit the unfortunate business between our two lands to be a thing of the past, and join hands as close neighbors and bosom friends in the coming years.
It would appear we've navigated the waters successfully—for today at least.
And Lord Caspar appears to have returned to his quarters, so all seems well for now. What say you, Cat Sìth?
Hmm? Oh, sure, I guess it'll be fine.
Well that's not very reassuring! And you call yourself my pactwyrm.
Can you blame me? Observing that man's every move is boring.
Of course it is. We're not doing this for the sake of your amusement.
The chill in your words is hardly necessary.
Forgive us, Cat Sìth. We'll be in your debt if you can only assist for a little while yet.
Mrow, I am not especially bothered. But is it really true?
Is he to be assassinated?
There is a faction in Raywall that would leap at the chance to see us at war with Grams once more.
So it seems. A-purr-ently they remain resentful of the previous engagement.
Yet said previous war was fought over ten years ago, was it not? Surely you humans do not live long enough to carry such animosity for so long?
It's true, we do not live quite so long as you dragons, but old grudges can survive many years in our hearts.
There are many people who fought with Grams personally, and others who lost parents, siblings, and children to them.
The problem is that it was not just Raywall who was at war—Grams was as well.
So then Grams has its own share of individuals who seek war?
Indeed, and Lord Caspar is the one holding that faction in check.
Were he to die, public sentiment in Grams would shift toward war in an eyeblink.
The war faction has long hoped for such an incident, and I suspect they will not pass up this opportunity.
We cannot let our eye on Lord Caspar waiver, not even for an instant.
If the enemy is aware that we have set a strong watch, it will make it harder for them to meddle. We absolutely must put a stop to the assassination.
...Then the target is not Caspar?
No. We aim for Priestess Aurelia.
As its name suggests, the Holy City is a place where the Ilian Church's influence is quite strong.
And that influence will reach a zenith— far outstripping even high government officials—with the murder of such an important and beloved priestess.
Grams will not take to silence if the assassination is a success.
In other words, it will be war, just as we desire.
Go and see this done. For the sake of our dream, failure will not be tolerated.
Worry not. With their guard this light, I would have to try to fail.
Elua is under the impression that we are targeting Caspar, and he will be well- protected indeed.
But that will make it far easier to twist the knife on Aurelia while their attention is distracted.
Failing at this task when they've left the door wide would be an insult to assassins everywhere. I will send a report soon when the deed is done.
We look forward to it.
(This is Aurelia's room... Seems like she's fast asleep.)
(I regret the thought of taking a woman's life, but it is your birth in Grams that wrongs you, priestess—not I.)
Hngh!
Nothing? ...No! It can't be!
How unfortunate for you.
Worry not! Priestess Aurelia has been moved to location most secure.
You're the princess! B-but how did...?!
I presume you mean ＂How did we know that you were actually going to target Priestess Aurelia＂?
Truthfully, it's far stranger why you thought we WOULDN'T know.
With your objective of fomenting strife with Grams so plain, it was a simple matter to suss out your plans.
Hrk!
And now, I believe I'll have you explain who it is that you work for.
You believe I would sell my comrades out? Perhaps that is how it works among you foul royals, but you'll find I'm made of sterner stuff!
I'd warn you not to be arrogant enough to believe you can take me on your own.
My, but I wonder which of us is truly the arrogant one. Perhaps it's time to teach you some regret for having besmirched the dragon bloodline!
Are you quite all right, Princess?
Ah, Lord Elua! Just in time. You'll find our miscreant lying there.
Rest easy, I did not kill him; I merely gave him a little caress.
Fascinating! This is no mean cutpurse, yet you handled him like a child.
I suppose that's what it is to be pactbound to a dragon. You surprise me yet again.
Why, it is I who is surprised, Lord Eula! I never would have believed that you might use Priestess Aurelia as bait.
Though we may bandy about titles for my person like ＂lord＂ and ＂marquis,＂ my position here is actually rather weak.
I am discomfited to admit this, but even within this city, I find myself not knowing who my true friends and enemies are.
To protect my territory, it sometimes behooves me to adopt bolder measures.
Yet if you only wanted to protect Priestess Aurelia, you had but to strengthen her guard as you did with Lord Caspar.
It is as you surmise, Princess Chelle: I would have been most chagrined had the war faction given up its assassination.
Had they failed to act, I would have lost a golden opportunity to learn who is masterminding their efforts.
To that end, I felt there was little option other than to imperil the good priestess.
Do you judge me for it?
Heh heh... Eeeeee hee hee hee!
Judge you? What possible reason could I have for such contempt?
Indeed, I was just thinking that things are likely to go quite well with you.
Don't you agree, my betrothed?
Princess Chelle!
Your timing is excellent, Lord Elua. Might you care to join me for tea?
Though I am honored by the offer, I'm afraid I've another matter I must discuss with you at the moment.
What could be more important than tea?
I have learned of the individual who masterminded the attempted assassination of Priestess Aurelia.
And who was it, pray tell?!
General Bertrand.
Hmm...
The general distinguished himself well with his service in the previous war.
Yet at the same time, he also faced the greatest of its hardships.
Which would prove ample basis for him to bear a potent grudge against Grams, as well as discontent towards the royal family for the cessation of hostilities.
...Yes, I did get that feeling from him.
What nerve to come over here! You're either fearless or brainless— I don't know which.
Intimidation through blackmail hardly befits one of your standing, Princess.
Though he also did not seem the type of man to resort to assassination.
I did not wish to believe it myself, but the information is beyond reproach.
So what do you intend to do?
As you would imagine, I cannot ignore such a thing. I will go to his residence forthwith and take him into custody.
Do you not think that rather hasty?! Such a high-handed display may well invite an eruption from the war faction.
Perhaps, but if it becomes known that our aim is to detain the general, it's possible his guard could be fortified.
We cannot match the forces under his command, so if it came to that, we would be hard-pressed indeed to call him to account for his actions.
We've no other option but to take our chances here and now.
Hmm...
I say, what is the meaning of this?!
Just as it appears, General Bertrand: You are being detained.
For what possible reason?!
Surely you haven't so quickly forgotten your attempt to assassinate an important person from the Holy City?
Don't be absurd! I would never engage in such base treachery!
You are a proud man, and I doubted it myself at first—but when I followed the trail of the would-be assassin, your name was the one that came up.
What?! There must be some mistake... Or perhaps... Marquis, do not allow yourself to be deceived. This is clearly some sort of plot!
Of course, even I am not so given to jumping to conclusions that I would see you beheaded on the spot.
However, attempting to bring harm to persons of import from foreign lands is a matter of dire national consequence.
I am left with no other choice but to turn you over to the capital and see you tried in the royal court. I trust the truth will prevail.
The royal court? Ha! That lot knows nothing of ＂truth＂! They would turn their backs on all manner of truth if it meant keeping their precious peace intact!
You need not worry about that; I have asked my father, King Aurelius, to ensure a strictly fair and impartial trial.
However, Lord Elua—in this matter alone, General Bertrand and I are of one mind.
I beg your pardon?!
The general commands all the forces of Raywall. If conflict were his aim, he could avail himself of any number of methods to achieve thus.
Skulking about in the shadows does not fit with the general's personality.
Princess, I...
Do you not think it possible you are being manipulated as the general suggests?
We have already discussed this matter. If we release the general now, we may never have a chance to take him again.
And if we later find that he is, in fact, the shadow behind the curtain, justice will mostlike never be served.
I apologize that I am unable to accept your opinion in the matter, but this is Raywall, and I am her marquis.
I must prioritize my own judgment. I trust this is acceptable to you, General?
In the past, I have found myself vexed by your meek attitude and hoped to see you make such firm decisions...
The irony of it finally coming as I am to be clapped in irons and led away a criminal is not lost upon me.
As the lord of Raywall, I will never forget those words. ...Now seize him.
Yes, sir!
(Whyever are you in such a hurry to see this deed done, my lord...?)
Raywall Suburbs
...Right. It appears we're all here.
Raywall's great strength is a thing of the past, seeing how easily we were able to make our way across her border.
It has been more than ten years since the ceasefire. There are few still vigilant after all this time.
So they're nothing without their key general, then.
You have no doubts about the situation with him, I trust?
He was transferred to the royal capital several days ago and is presently on the journey. Whatever happens in Raywall will take place without his presence.
Raywall's capitulation will now be easier than taking sweets from a child.
Framing the linchpin of the Raywall army as an insurrectionist and banishing him from the city was a clever plan.
I was skeptical at first, but it seems to have worked out rather nicely.
The plan took several years to form and execute; I should be quite distraught had it not gone to perfection.
Well, ALMOST to perfection.
How unfortunate that I have to see you in such a sad state.
Don't you think, Lord Elua?
Princess Chelle? How did you...?
I've been shadowing you all along. Blending into the darkness is something of a forte of meowne.
You're not going to try and explain your way out of it at this late stage, are you?
It is clear you are colluding with Grams in order to sell out Raywall.
But why? Your will to protect Raywall felt true, so why have you done this thing?
I do it TO protect her!
I may have fomented this unrest, but it is nonetheless true that Raywall seeks war.
The tide is inevitable, and there is little I can do to hold it back at this point.
Even without my actions, Raywall and Grams would have gone to war eventually.
So you sought to make Raywall fall to Grams before the war could even begin?
Just so. If war were to ever break out, lives would be lost and the city set to burn.
To save Raywall, I have no recourse but to put her in a state where war cannot occur.
Do you understand the consequences such a plan could incur?
The army of Grams will not be satisfied with Raywall alone, and the flames of war will soon lick at all Alberia.
You would save Raywall at the expense of some other city elsewhere.
Indeed. And what of it?
Then you don't care at all for what might happen beyond your city walls?!
I know what you will say: Such a thing is cruel. Unjust, and despicable, and you would not have me impose tragedy upon others in order to spare ourselves.
Yet that is exactly what happened to US all those years ago!
WE were the only ones engulfed in the flames fanned by the previous war! The whole of the nation leaned on our strength and gained from our sacrifice!
That is why I swore a vow to give all that I am to protect this city and territory from such a cruel fate ever again.
No matter the injustices I may have to perpetrate, or the dishonor I may be forced to weather.
I see...
Are you disappointed, Princess Chelle? You ought to understand.
Nobility has a duty to bear responsibility for their people—to protect their lives and livelihoods. Is that not so?
It is. Nobility is not merely something to be relished, but a status that brings with it the responsibility to safeguard others.
Then you und—
But you have abandoned it.
Abandoned what?
Being noble.
You admit to caring not a whit for what occurs outside Raywall, which means your nobility ends at the city gates.
If I am disappointed, it is not because of your cruelty, but your limited ambition!
You have surpassed me, my fiancée.
You possess such a small view of yourself, Lord Elua. You know this, yes?
Even if there were truth to that, I will not give credit to my own capabilities at this point—so let this serve as our farewell.
Is the discussion ended, Marquis?
Yes. Pray forgive me for the delay. You may now deploy your troops to Raywall as we previously arranged.
Being discovered by Princess Chelle was a blunder, but even were she to raise a fuss, all will be over and done with by then.
I wonder about that.
G-General Bertrand?! Impossible!
You'll likely leap to this conclusion soon, but I'll save you the trouble and just admit that I halted the transfer of the general to the capital.
You cannot possibly believe I came here without any sort of plan?
Unfortunately for you, I am not such a romantic that I believed I could put a stop to your machinations with the power of love.
Hrk...
Nor am I here empty-handed, Marquis— you will find I lead a considerable force of every man and woman I could mobilize.
Even if your forces were to attack them head-on, I rather like our chances.
Dastard!
And on that note, Lord Caspar, might you care to make a deal?
What do you mean?!
I assume you do not wish to start a war with Raywall at this time, correct?
In that case, perhaps it might be better to decide that it never happened?
That WHAT never happened?
Why, the Grams army having crossed the national border, of course! I would decide that such a transgression never happened.
This is acceptable to you?
That rests entirely on you—but I would suggest that our good relations continuing on as they have in the past would be reward enough.
G-good relations?!
Indeed. I shall send along invitations to parties once more.
It would seem you are better at this game than the Marquis of Raywall... Very well, Princess. All troops, withdraw!
It is finished, Lord Elua.
It does appear that way.
I will be transferring you to the capital so you might face the judgment of the royal court.
Poetic justice, I suppose—but I am ready for whatever decision they may hand down.
I wish only that I had met you sooner, Lord Elua. If so, perhaps...
Stop. You mustn't have such regrets. All of this was brought on by the meagerness of my abilities alone.
Forget about this man lacking in ambition, and continue to walk forward with nobility and grace, Princess.
That would be a small solace for me.
...My, but time does fly. How meowny years has it been?
But now that Chanzelia has finally come together, is it really the right time to up and abandon the territory?
It may well scatter once more in your absence, sad as that is to contemplate.
Goodness, do you think I have been cultivating an organization that can be taken down in the mere absence of a ruler or two?
And besides, this will be the perfect opportunity. Certainly, my priorities lie with Euden, but...
I was just thinking it was time to thank the people of the Holy City of Grams for what happened that day... Eee hee hee!
*sigh* I know not what will occur in the north, but it sounds as if it certainly will not be boring.
And I wouldn't have it any other way. Now let us be off, Cat Sìth!
By the way, Chelle?
I've wanted to ask you this for some time: Why did you change the name from Raywall to Chanzelia?
Because Raywall was the name of a traitor.
And I believed it would be better to erase such a thing entirely.
For I must continue to walk forward with nobility and grace.
(...Isn't that right, Lord Elua?)
